"Captain Phillips" is a cold-water treatment for anyone who regards pirates solely based on what they see at the movies - or on the internet for that matter.  If your mental imagery of high seas plunderers begins and ends with Jack Sparrow, then you're in for a shock when director Paul Greengrass puts his arm around your shoulder and shows you - in cold, spare detail - how it works in the real world.

The story of "Captain Phillips" is based on the 2009 attempted high jacking of the cargo ship MV Maersk Alabama, 200 miles off the coast of Somalia, and the subsequent kidnapping of merchant mariner Captain Richard Phillips (Tom Hanks).  Little time is wasted on getting things rolling.  We are hardly 20 minutes into the film when the pirates, driving two skiff boats, begin closing in on the ship which they choose because it is the only ship in the region that isn't sailing close to another ship.  Greengrass bypasses a lot of introductory scenes in an attempt to keep the story lean and spare.  He establishes only that Phillips has a wife (Catherine Keener) and that the Somalis banded their pirate crew together early that morning on the beach, like employers looking for day laborers.  After that, the movie is full-steam ahead into a white-knuckle thriller that Greengrass is able to keep tense even when we know how it ends.

The scenes of the takeover are laid out with scary precision.  The Alabama attempts to subvert the takeover by first outrunning and then out-maneuvering the skiff.  The action is presented with such dramatic tension that we begin to think, for a moment, that the Alabama might be able to avoid the takeover.   That, of course, is not the truth.  The ship is boarded by four young Somali men who are skinny, frightened and waving machine guns.

We learn only what we need to know about the characters.  Phillips is shown as a man of experience, who is able to improvise at crucial moments.  Hanks downplays his performance by making it mostly reactionary.  He doesn't pose for effect, but simply plays to the moment.  He saves his one huge emotional moment for last.  Hanks is an actor who is as familiar to us as a favorite cousin, and after 33 years of acting in professional films, we think that we might have seen everything that his acting arsenal might have to offer.  He has a moment in this film of near-emotional meltdown that is startling.  It is a moment that, up until now, this fine actor has never been able to display.

The pirates themselves redefine the words "rag-tag."  There are only four men left when the hijack actually happens - several others abandoned the mission.  At first they seem like movie types:  There's a hard-eyed leader, a hot-head, a scared kid, and one guy who might be mistaken for having a soul.  They have a goal in mind, but these are not professional criminals.  They are scared, violent and hard-headed.  Early and often, they make stupid mistakes because, determined as they are, they're not exactly brainiacs.

Most of their focus comes from the leader, Abduwali Muse (Barkhad Adbi) who earns no sympathy even when he tells Phillips his reasons for taking the ship - he, like, Phillips, has people to answer to.  Adbi is an untrained actor making his film debut and is already earning buzz as a possible Oscar contender.  It might be well earned.  He doesn't play Muse as irrational.  There's something in his eyes that tells us that he is determined to take this crisis to a tragic end.  We actually begin to believe that in other circumstances, he could make an effective leader - or a fearsome warlord.

Greengrass keeps the film lean and sharp.  He builds tension, not out of phony manipulation, but based on circumstance and fact.  He's an old hat at this kind of thing.  He previously directed "Bloody Sunday", about the 1972 Irish civil rights march and subsequent massacre by British troops.  He also made the brilliant "United 93" about the plane that crashed in Pennsylvania on September 11th.

He's a craftsman who knows how to stage a real-life action scenes without pumping it full of phony drama.  He sticks to the moment.  "Captain Phillips" is a very well-made recreation of a real-life event.  What it does it does very well.  It doesn't have much meaning beyond itself, however.  It is an incident that happened in real life, but there are not a lot of personal details.  Once it's over you're only left with a great thriller.  As with "United 93," (which was my favorite film of 2006) Greengrass wants to stick to the facts, and not burden the film with side-stories.  That's probably best because he's better at the documentary details than he is with characters and personal drama.  Still, this is probably the most effective thriller you'll see all year.

Have Camera, Will Shake

Dear Mr. Greengrass, your signature style using a nervous camera and jarring edits from start to finish has become all too tired and cliché. Although you seem to have cornered the market on shooting in choppy environments (hijacked planes and ships), your MO is wonky and outdated. It once provided us with the illusion of edgy unpredictability but no longer substitutes for good story-telling and suspenseful drama. It was fun for a while but substance outlives style. Next time out, unpack the tripod, see if you can't restrain those spasms.

The docudrama appearance of the film is at odds with it's Hollywood makeover and spoiled by casting a movie star in the title role. We can actually believe those were real Somali pirates stalking the ship, barefoot in a motorboat with a machine gun, so what's Tom Hanks doing out there? 

Which captain is more likely to be nominated for an Oscar and which one is more deserving, Tom Hanks, the extremely likable hard-luck chap, or Barkhad Abdi, the very convincing "skinny" Somalian in his first acting role? "Relax, everything's going to be okay, Mr. Phillips." 

The story was initially framed from two opposing points of view. But for all the time we spend with the Captain and the pirates, we know very little about them. He's married. They are desperate. End of profile. This is why the endings of such undeveloped stories are abrupt and unsatisfying. The scrappy character development is ultimately why the movie needs illustrious old Tom Hanks and the indelible memory of his previous fictional characters. And, without question, a shaky camera.

Much of the dialogue was reduced to short outbursts of threats and fits of rage. The movie could have been released on Twitter. It rang rather empty when Hanks roared out they were not fishermen, since neither he or the audience knew much about them. Given his strategic thinking, you'd figure Phillips would have tried to sympathize with the attackers, get to know them, if only to weaken their resolve and possibly get them to turn against each other. Besides, isn't this what displaced main characters are meant to do? Be our eyes and ears in a narrative of conflict and discovery?

The Somalian Pirates fail to impress us as anything but deadly pests. Their crude onrush leaves me wondering why the most self-important nation on earth, so insanely obsessed and possessive about firearms, doesn't at least provide the old Cap with a pocket pistol for self-defence? Seriously, the only weapons provided for these gigantic container ships, so vital to a global economy, are water hoses?

Some of the more interesting facts and details seemed to either be swept aside or glossed over. The pirates, for all their maniacal posturing, did not kill anyone. Attacking them was like swatting a mosquito with a wrecking ball. The absurdity is evident but never appeared foolish as the filmmakers brazenly flaunted conventional American propaganda. Disproportionately heroic American might and justice was never questioned.(The cost of hiring a warship perhaps?) 

The desperation of the pirates mission was touched upon: return with the ship and/or the captain or face certain death. But the resolve of the American naval SEAL to rescue a single individual using its highly skilled and lopsided military was never in doubt. Thus, staking its claim on the foolhardy impression that every individual American life is sacred (if your white, well-to-do and married) but never once hinted that it was likely for the optics alone. This is typically implied by showing TV news coverage of the hostage crisis back home, often from the protagonist's family room. 

We were introduced to his wife in the first scene but never see her again. Actually, I don't mind this omission. The movie succeeds rather well keeping us in the moment with a tense, rigid, alert objective in lieu of a broader and richer perspective. I got the feeling something important was happening--but little else.

A tense, solid maritime film with some fantastic performances and a gripping screenplay, this true-story drama from Paul Greengrass is a fantastic piece of filmmaking.

The film follows the titular Captain Richard Phillips, the captain that was taken hostage on a small lifeboat by a group of desperate Somali pirates. Phillips initially tries to fight off the small band of rogues, but once he is defeated, he tries to learn a bit more about them, and through him, the audience is subjected to a surprisingly sympathetic - although certainly not rosy - image of the pirates and their own motives.

The film stars Tom Hanks and Catherine Keener, and also leaves plenty of roles open for unknown Somali actors to fill. One such role, that of the pirate leader Abduwali Muse, went to Barkhad Abdi, who portrayed so many layers to a character that could easily have been a caricature. That performance earned Abdi a well-deserved Academy Award nomination, but unfortunately he couldn't beat Jared Leto to the award.

It's a tense film (probably made more tense from my perspective as I was actually sailing on a boat when I watched this), and incredibly well-made, despite a little bit of shaky cam coming in. The writing was also superb. Just an intense film all around.

Review In A Nutshell:

Captain Phillips was a film, I have been eager to see since its release as it was under the direction of Paul Greengrass, who has made some of the most of entertaining and thought provoking action/thriller films of the 21st century; Bourne Supremacy and Ultimatum, and the underrated Green Zone. Months have gone by, almost everyone has seen the film and most have praised it; therefore seeing and reading them, allowed my expectations to build, thinking that this film might actually be Greengrass' opus. Now that I have seen it, does the film live up to the hype? Yes, but only just.

The premise of Captain Phillips is certainly not original, but originality has never been something I look for in a Greengrass film. In his films, I search for heightened emotions gained from masterfully crafted sequences; building tension and maintaining it throughout. Very filmmakers could maintain tension and suspense in their films, let alone create it. The bulk of the film is driven by dialogue and Greengrass was able to create so much out of it; demanding intensity from his cast's performances and supporting it with his trademark collaboration with Barry Ackroyd, that delivers effective shaky-cam effects in its photography; using that to create the sense of claustrophobia and its adverse effects of frustration, fear and trauma on both sides of the event. This is what makes Captain Phillips more than just the average hostage film; it actually takes the time to explore both sides of the situation. These Somali pirates are not just seen as villains, they are also viewed as humans who show reasoning behind their decisions; which in this case are ego, pride, and survival. The film primarily contrasts two characters, Phillip and Muse; both are captains of their own side, and the film wonderfully shows us the necessity of their leadership in ensuring their objectives and responsibilities are being met. Tom Hanks and Barkhad Abdi brought so much to their characters, making them feel believable in their roles, showing little in their exteriors but one can feel their internal emotions. Then we are treated to a final moment with Hanks, that brings a wide range of emotions to the surface and show the impact that the situation has had on him. I was also left kind of sympathetic rather than achieving a feeling of triumph towards the antagonists, during the final moments of the film; and I have Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks' final scene to thank for that.

Captain Phillips, so far under my eyes, may not be Paul Greengrass' best film, but it certainly is his intimate; with its sense of claustrophobia and exploration into the minds and emotions of its leading characters. Captain Phillips was an exhilarating and heavy ride.

Then we are treated to a final moment with Hanks, that brings a wide range of emotions to the surface and show the impact that the situation has had on him. I was also left kind of sympathetic rather than achieving a feeling of triumph towards the antagonists, during the final moments of the film; and I have Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks' final scene to thank for that.

Captain Phillips, so far under my eyes, may not be Paul Greengrass' best film, but it certainly is his intimate; with its sense of claustrophobia and exploration into the minds and emotions of its leading characters. Captain Phillips was an exhilarating and heavy ride.

The film must overcome the spoiler effect of being about a current event, and in general does a good job, although it lacks the nail-biting zip of a thriller where the ending is very much in doubt. There can't be any twists. The SEALs are fated to take out the pirates and rescue Captain Phillips. Tom Hanks' Vermont accent sounds more generic New England than Green Mountain State, but most people aren't going to be able to tell unless they've spent a lot of time there. He's good, but not brilliant in the role. I can't think of anyone else who could have bested him. I credit the director for not making this a bash the USA and globalization spectacle. There's been enough of that lately. I'm sure nobody in Hollywood wants to look like they are opposed to Saint Obama, who authorized the use of deadly force in this case. I haven't heard of very many ship hijackings lately. I think the shipping companies got the message and have hired some rough men with assault rifles and telescopic sights to keep the Somalis at bay. Besides, all they really need to do is emigrate to the USA and they won't need to be criminals. They'll get it handed to them.

Based on the true story from 2009 of a cargo ship captain being hijacked by pirates off the coast of Somalia, Captain Phillips is film full of suspense. Tom Hanks plays Captain Phillips as he prepares the best a person can prepare for the inevitability of pirates attempting to take his ship ransom.

Quickly the movie sets the foundation for Captain Phillips background, a captain who is doing a dangerous job, despite his wife's wishes, because there would be a line of men willing. Simultaneously the foundation is set for the pirates, boat loads of Somali men volunteering to hijack a ship, because this is a somber reality of life with no true alternative for livelihood. The crew, Navy, and audience wait as Richard Phillips is put in the perilous position of negotiator and hostage. The pirates are never as brutal as they have to be and the American crew members are never as heroic as they need to be.

Hanks does a more than adequate job as a sympathizer to the pirates, trying to get everyone out of the situation intact and alive. This selfless and heroic character is probably not accurate to the real Captain Phillips persona, but necessary as a counter view to the pirates' story. I found myself identifying with the pirates, hoping they would have some sense, despite knowing the end to the story. This is thanks in part to the main Somali pirate, Muse, played by Barkhad Abdi. I am thankful he has received as many accolades as he has, though not a trained actor, he turns out a multi-layered character under tragic circumstances.

This movie easily could have been a one-sided telling of the brutalities of the pirates, instead you get a multidimensional story that is more about the current effects of globalization than the thrilling encounter.

The story of "Captain Phillips" was huge news in 2009 as a large container ship, the MV Maersk Alabama, was boarded by pirates off the coast of Somalia. In an age of rampant terrorism, the story was headline news and was so highly publicized that the President of the United States got involved, along with the Navy Seals. To many, it was shocking news that this sort of thing happens. Pirates? Really? These aren't Jack Sparrow, Captain Hook type pirates, these are desperate, vicious, poor pirates in small boats with nothing to lose. These are pirates who are for the most part, under orders of bigger controlling groups who pray upon the desperate lifestyles of the Somali people.

Much has been said about the accuracy of the book written by Captain Phillips, "A Captain's Duty: Somali Pirates, Navy Seals, and Dangerous Days at Sea" and now the movie, "Captain Phillips". In fact, many of the crew of the Maersk Alabama are now suing Captain Phillips for wantonly and arrogantly putting them in danger. They are telling stories that completely contradict much of what you see in the film leading up to the pirates boarding their ship. This to me is extremely disappointing if their stories are true. I believe it is irresponsible for movie-makers to misrepresent history. Many people take the easy way out when learning about history and movies leave a huge impression on their minds.

That being said, I assume that most of the movie is completely accurate as most of what happened after the pirates boarded is documented by news outlets and the Navy Seals. Director Paul Greengrass handled the true story with a realistic eye. He's made a niche for himself with 7-true story films, the most recognizable of those being "United 93". His staging of events is engrossing, vivid and at times tough to watch.

"Captain Phillips" is listed as an action/thriller, but those viewing the film would be quick to mention that this movie shouldn't be lumped in with the typical action movie. I would consider "Captain Phillips" more a drama than an action/thriller. You are side by side Captain Phillips (Tom Hanks) through this realistic and horrible incident with pirates who cannot be accused of being intelligent, but are certainly without a morale code or an alternative to their actions.

The movie is tough to watch at times and possibly a little long, but for the most part it is an amazing look inside one of the biggest news stories of 2009. The pirates, although portrayed realistically are infuriating to watch and annoying to watch. From beginning to end they are amazingly fool-minded, disorganized and constantly angrily yelling. I agree that these portrayal's are probably extremely accurate, but as a movie, they are like listening to 10 people yelling different stories at each other for over an hour.

"Captain Phillips" is not for everybody and there's a reason why the creators called this an action/thriller. If they told you what it really was, you probably wouldn't go. "Captain Phillips" is not fun to watch and far from thrilling. It is not filled with harrowing and exciting bravery at every corner. It is not filled with twists and turns. It is a dirty, difficult and drudging film that tells the story of real people in a horrible and real situation. If you like that sort of thing, go see it. Not a repeat viewer type thing though. The terrorists are annoying and the subject matter is depressing.

Captain Philips - the movie: Wow. Still reeling with admiration for this most riveting, meaningful, terrifying, moving portrayal of a real life story.  Finally rented it on DVD last night. It's one of those movies I feel compelled to talk about because I can't stop thinking about it - now 24 hours later. Thrilling, intense, nail-biting, it is also morally complex and tragic.
One of the best things about renting it on DVD was being able to watch the 1-hour "making-of" documentary immediately afterwards, which was almost as riveting and fascinating as the movie itself.
The Somali pirates who attack Captain Philips' ship are so real. They're played by real Somali born young men (now living in the US) who have never acted in a movie before. They've been given several months of training by the director, and they do a phenomenal job. They give a menacing authenticity to the movie. The director deliberately kept them apart from the other team of actors - (i.e. Tom Hanks and his crew on board the ship) - not allowing them to meet socially off set before the movie shooting, so that when these Somalis first climb aboard and storm in to the bridge screaming and wielding their AK-47s, they create a genuine atmosphere of terror, anxiety and tension.
Two time Oscar winner, Tom Hanks, doesn't need help acting of course, but the fear in this scene (and the rest of the movie) is so palpable, it's easy to see why many critics are saying this could be his best performance yet. And he really was fantastic. I've always been a big Hanks fan, and this just continues to reinforce my opinion of him as one of the greats. He's just so darn professional, talented, extraordinary, and deeply moving. The other supporting actors are all very realistic too, and it was satisfying to see (in the documentary) how much research they all did into portraying the typical lives of these sailors on board these cargo ships. The making-of documentary was a great way to see just how much work they ALL put into this movie, line by line, moment by moment, scene by scene. It very much reminded me of the process of recording my professional choir CDs. Performing phrases, words and lines over and over again, until you reach as near perfection as possible, with the director steering you at every turn.
What I also found deeply satisfying was the way the movie gave us the background stories, not only of Philips' life and that of his American crew, but also of the Somali pirates. The movie makes them human individuals that we can't help sympathizing with because of the tragic, violent and meaningless lives they are forced to lead. It does not mask or gloss over the heinousness of their criminal trade, but shows their desperation, their poverty, their crazed frenzy to assert what little power they have, and try to earn a sense of worth, even if it is tragically misguided, and even if it is only to "please" their war-mongering war-lords. After watching the documentary, and finding out more about the Somali pirates - I felt this even more strongly. It was especially heartening to watch the interview afterwards, with the actor, Barkhad Abdi, who plays the lead pirate (Muse), and hear him talk with deep emotion about lucky he himself was to be able to get out of Somalia at the age of 14 with his family, and settle in the US and make a better life, and "be a better person."
Besides the moral and political aspects of the movie, it was also just tons of fun to watch the thrilling chase of the pirates by the full fleet of the US Navy in all its military glory. At one point, I really felt like I was watching a particularly good Star Trek episode, where aliens were invading and the U.S.S. Enterprise had called in reinforcements to battle them. All the naval terms and phrases: - "5 degrees starboard", and the official naval talk over the radios during the fast paced chase and rescue scene - was very much star-ship thriller material - except this wasn't a star ship, this was a real ship! This was a thriller at its best, with all the elements of nail-biting suspense, swift, heart-thudding action, twist and turns and tension right up until the very emotional end.
It was particularly thrilling to watch the real Captain Richard Philips being interviewed in the documentary afterwards, to get some more bits of the story from his own lips, and to see this real-life hero, clearly affected by, but not beaten down by, his ordeal. An admirable man, and an admirable tale of bravery and endurance, brilliantly portrayed and honored by this movie.
At the end of it, you are reeling with the multi-layered morals and messages you've just been given. It's a tale of a heroic Captain in peril on the high seas, and the awe-inspiring military rescue he is given by the mighty US Navy. But it's also a tragic tale of the miserable, crazed, desperate, power thirsty men of Somalia, beaten down by a country that has no economy, no structure, no education, no hope to offer, other than idle threats and empty promises. At the end, you wonder, you hope, that one day, maybe, this tragic situation might eventually be changed, helped, resolved somehow, with time and development... This movie (and many others like it) may help generate a global awareness, if nothing else, and maybe a passion for change for the better.

Captain Phillips is Paul Greengrass (Bloody Sunday, United 93)' tightly-wound retelling of the hijacking of the Maersk Alabama in 2009 - the first such incident involving an American vessel in well over 100 years. It's a film that sells itself on the appeal of director Greengrass' punchy, fast-paced storytelling, but benefits from a powerhouse performance, courtesy of Tom Hanks, and Greengrass' own innate ability to blend narrative weight with the higher-stakes action. For a populist film (my filmically uninclined friend called it the best movie he's seen in a while), it explores a number of interesting themes, including class divide, the justification of piracy, and the lengths a man will go to in the defense of his life and those of others.


Hanks carries the film as Richard Phillips, captain of an unarmed container ship making the journey from Oman to Mombasa, travelling around the Horn of Africa. Of course, the ship is targeted by Somali pirates (who saw that one coming?), and Phillips enters into a very dangerous battle of wits with the pirates, led by young Somalian, Muse (Barkhad Abdi, in a breakout role). For the most part, Greengrass does a fantastic job at portraying the high stakes of Phillips' confrontation with Muse, and the dire situation of the Maersk Alabama and her crew. His polarising use of quick shots, zoom-ins and shaky cam is put to good use, infusing an action movie quality to a mostly sober drama.

The doubtless highlight of the film comes in it's leads, who couldn't be more different. America's Best Friend Tom Hanks is Phillips, in what might be his best performance in over a decade. While Billy Ray's screenplay is said to divert from the real Phillips' persona, Hanks is as Hanks does, bringing a jaw-dropping realism to his performance. Every life-or-death decision he makes in the film is built on all the rationality a man can have in a hostage situation, and one can see the wheels turning in Hanks' head with every utterance. Simply put, it's a performance of tremendous magnitude, sampling a wide palette of emotions and sensations. It's a performance that would sell any film, and Hanks' Oscar snub still baffles.

On the other end of the gun, we have Barkhad Abdi. The film makes use of real Somalians to heighten the realism of an unnervingly realistic film, and Abdi is clearly the standout. Among his bigger stronger cohorts, Muse is calm and collected, speaking each word with an icy cool. Every utterance is a threat in disguise, and Abdi captures the layered nature of his character exceptionally well. For a first-time performance, it's a knockout, and Abdi deserved his Oscar nomination (in the year's toughest category).

The film, on a technical level, is moreso about what one likes as a viewer. If you can handle Paul Greengrass' oft-nauseating pace, then the film will work for you. His pseudo-documentary style, replete with dizzying cuts, close-ups, and zoom-ins, makes for a headache-inducing time, but his inclusion of tracking shots, wide shots, and establishing shots hold the film back from losing it's dramatic focus. Greengrass is occasionally guilty of stretching the film too much and letting it sag, leading to a few interminably dull, meandering scenes.

And that's where the film's greatest flaw appears. While Greengrass makes good use of Barry Ackyroyd's cinematography, and doesn't overdo the frenetic shots he's famous for, there comes a small number of times in the film where it seems like Greengrass simply loses sight of narrative finesse. It's understandable that a film based on true events can only tailor those events to suit it's subtext to a certain degree, but I was surprised by just how dull much of the film ended up being. The finale is excellent, and just about everything from it's first hour is engaging cinema, but between those points, the film spends far too long in an aimless drift, delivering none of the keen insight or great character development of earlier in the film.

Despite this, the film is bolstered by two powerhouse performances, each from a very different actor, both with very different material. Director Paul Greengrass makes great use of the confined settings of the film, and charges the film with social and economic themes reflective of it's time period. Billy Ray's screenplay is inconsistent, but the film's style and breakneck pace make up for it's uninspiring material. Ultimately, the film is a success on the back's of it's leads, and Greengrass' mostly sure-handed directorial talents. If it were a shade more consistent, I feel it would have better-merited it's six Oscar nominations.

Somalia has been country operating in the absence of government. Those in America speaking with a bit of levity might say that sounds pretty good right about now. In reality, this has brought forth a nation ravaged with war, poverty, disease, and hunger. In desperate times, many in the Horn region of Africa have turned to extremes, shunning livelihoods as fisherman for the acts of pirating ships for ransom. Captain Phillips spends very little time within the country itself,but through its characters, Director Paul Greengrass illustrates the clashes resulting from two paradigms, two crews, and two captains clashing near the coast of Africa in 2009.

Captain Richard Phillips steers his cargo vessel from the Middle Eastern country of Oman with an itinerary to Mombasa. In parallel, we are introduced to Abduwali Muse, a Somali fisherman with some clout as a tribal pirate, convincingly brought to life by acting rookie Barkhad Abdi. Muse's back story is minimal, simply introducing him with the goal of explaining his motivations and ambitions, but stopping just short of evoking sympathy. These analogous prologues introduce two unequal worlds, and also two captains who only operate within their own rules; both are natural, yet flawed, leaders.

Muse leads a "crew" to take over the MV Maersk Alabama, Phillips's ship, hoping to evoke a ransom that shipping companies seem to accept in this part of the world (Muse constantly explains that the "insurance man" will come and "make everything alright"). Abdi establishes his presence on screen far before his American counterpart. He's simpleminded, as though piracy is all he's ever known, since fishing around the coast of Somalia is not a sustainable life anymore. This simplicity, however,is overwhelmed with a determination to succeed and perhaps make his way to America, a country he believes he is knowledgeable about.

Cinematography is often overlooked, partially because bad camera work is unfortunately more noticeable than a gifted craftsman behind the lens. I mention this because of the value-added Barry Ackroyd provides to Captain Phillips. To keep a story entrancing and tension sustained within the confines of a small space is not only a talent, but a necessity in this case. Additionally, the use of the shaky documentary-style shoot Greengrass is known for adds a dose of reality without the bout of nausea we usually have to endure. To peer through the windows of a small vessel and spot looming Navy vessels in the short distance evoked memories of similar shots in other waterborne films such as Master and Commanderand Pirates of the Caribbean.

Like movies should, Captain Phillips forces the audience to ask questions. The most obvious, and more important to those depicted in the film, is why the protocol for piracy isn't more efficient in that part of the world?

Moreover, Hanks begs us to answer the question: what would you do in this situation? This second question is more important in the eyes of the director, and should be for any making films in this genre. Action or thriller movies are effective when they are all-enveloping, capturing all of our senses in the moment on screen, and thrusting us into the foreground.Captain Phillips isn't as successful as some recent films in this respect: we don't feel the raw weight as in Prisoners or the fear of emptiness throughout Gravity.

But, having a veteran like Hanks on board rights the ship throughout. He's not a superhero, but he is far from latent. Always aware of the situation (the tension-filled crew, the necessity of preparedness), the veteran captain tries to control what little he can (acting as a first-aid agent on the lifeboat). The influence he has on the rest of the crew (film and ship) is just what makes this film come together. You'll be very aware of his performance and ability in this film just prior to the curtain dropping; his raw emotion is awe-inspiring.

Despite some questionable scene transitions and indeterminate timeline, Captain Phillips is intriguing and fresh. The mood of this film is far more upbeat than recent releases, but is topped with a note of intensity and seriousness we're used to in these types of films.

A cargo ship captain must preserve his and his crew's lives after their ship is hijacked by Somali pirates.
For most of this film, it is a solid, two-and-a-half- to three-star thriller.  The action is intense, and the plot moves along quickly.  It is in the last moments of the film, especially the phenomenally vulnerable turn by Tom Hanks, that makes this film worth watching.
The film's attempts to humanize the Somali pirates fails - not miserably but fails nonetheless.  We get shots of Somali poverty, the Somali social order, and the trailer-publicize line, "Maybe in America," but these moments don't amount to much because by the end of the film, there's no real understanding or human sympathy possible on the part of either the characters or the audience.  The Somalis are unquestioned bad guys; director Paul Greengrass might as well have given them red light sabers.
Overall, Hanks's performance is strong and the film is a good addition to the thriller genre.

A movie adaptation of the Maersk Alabama hijacking, Captain Phillips is a mixed bag on paper. The very talented Paul Greengrass, coupled with Tom Hanks who fits the role of Richard Phillips perfectly create a stark contrast to the unproven acting talent in the Somali cast, who are featured almost as heavily as Hanks. I didn't have any expectations going to see it, so was happy to discover how well it actually turned out.

The film begins with some simple exposition. It's dull stuff, but provides context and an opportunity to aquatint ourselves with characters not only in the Alabama, but on the pirate side of the story. The pirates themselves are newcomers, but all do extremely well. Barkhad Abdi deserves particular note for his role which has a close symmetry to Richard Phillips and helps to paint the pirates as vividly human, and not just another force of evil.

Hanks performance is terrific as normal, but it's the last five minutes of it that will blow you away, and left me on the verge of tears. It was completely unexpected and gives every bit of respect that the real life story deserves.

The whole film builds stress on top of tension and it creates scenes which can be genuinely difficult to watch, especially as the times goes on. Greengrass uses his signature shaky-cam frequently, and to varying success. When done right it can really lead to moments which feel real and terrifying, while it's continued use in the quieter moments of the film can pull you out of an otherwise very engrossing film.

Also guaranteed to divide opinion is the soundtrack. It works very well, but it's also often just a (admittedly good) remix of Inception. The chords are obviously the same, as is the instrumentation. Again, in the movie it sounds great and I'm aware that the composer is close to Hans Zimmer, but it's still a blatant cut and paste job which in my opinion works against the film.

In truth though, at this point I'm nitpicking. Well directed and acted, Captain Phillips suffers occasionally from some cinematography issues and a slightly lacking second act. But is also a tense and thoroughly enjoyable movie, and one of the best "true story" films that I've watched in a very long time.

Directed by Paul Greengrass, (The Bourne Supremacy (2004), United 93 (2006), The Bourne Ultimatum (2007) and Green Zone (2010)), this true life action thriller was based on the 2010 book A Captain's Duty: Somali Pirates, Navy SEALs, and Dangerous Days at Sea by Richard Phillips with Stephan Talty. It's a suspenseful and moody film which is focused and to the point with a good cast. When Captain Richard Phillips (Tom Hanks) is assigned to command the MV Maersk Alabama from Oman to Mombasa, Kenya. It seems just like another job, but it will mean navigating dangerous waters where Somali Pirates are rife, and it happens here. 4 pirates, led by Abduwali Muse (Barkhad Abdi), are able to catch up with the ship and board it, and they take Phillips hostage. They're unimpressed that the ship only holds $30,000. But after the crew fight back against the pirates in the engine room, they makes off in a lifeboat with Phillips as hostage, but the U.S. Navy Seals find them, and are determined to save Phillips. It's a very taut and tight thriller with some good moments of suspense. Hanks is brilliant as the brave captain just trying to stay alive, but the real life Somalians as the pirates, all non-actors, are brilliant, and it was a real coup getting them involved in the film, but their plight shown in the film is tragic and cruel as well.

Now in the book they portray the captain as heroic, like he came together and stopped those pirates, but in reality the rest of the crew said that he really just fucked everything up. But no matter what you believe, we all go into Hollywood looking at a biopic and thinking to ourselves that we are not really watching a real story. Or perhaps maybe half of it is true, or a quarter of it, but we all know it is not the whole true story. But whether you know about the story or you don't believe in it, one thing I can say is that this movie is what it is. I was expecting a very standard biopic and that is exactly what I got. So just sit right back and you'll hear a tale, a tale of a fateful trip. That started from a point of interest to just another meager review aboard this movie. 

The first half of this movie had me on the edge of my seat; but after those Somalian's boarded onto that big boat, and then later jumped into the smaller boat, I pretty much lost interest after that. Tom Hanks is playing, well....Tom Hanks but he still does a pretty god job at it. However I thought those Somalian's were really good in this movie, especially the leader of the group Muse who was played by Barkhad Abdi ("Yes" I did look him up on IMDB to find that actor). That guy could easily be on The Walking Dead with no extra makeup at all. The Somalian's are super intense, did a good job at building their characters (where we get to know each and every one of them), and as the movie goes on the more interesting things got in the lifeboat sequence as we see their relationship crumble between them & defining them as actual human beings. The drama in this movie is there along with some pretty decent dialogue to go with it. It is able to handle everything that you get to see in an action movie that works. Is has stealth, gunplay, narrow escapes, Wilson from Cast Away, etc. I say drama and not action is because it builds everything up to look like it has action, like taking out the bad guys one by one or explosions, but it never does and makes it a lot of sensible. I would not go far as to say that it was boring, however I started losing momentum in it. The momentum where it was good for the first half and the second half it just went a little too long and it is a long movie. Overall it is well done and hits all of the marks like it should, but for me I was ready for this thing to wrap up. It is easily a four stars all the way.

The entire movie could have been 40 minutes shorter I think. Overall, the acting was good and the plot kept you inattentive.

Back in 2009, the world was hit with the horrific story of the MV Maersk Alabama hijacking, which was the first official American ship to be seized by pirates since the early 19th century. The hero of this tale, merchant mariner Captain Richard Phillips, reportedly did his very best to save his crew and wound up getting taken as a hostage by four Somalian pirates led by Abduwali Muse before being rescued by U.S. Navy SEALs after a lengthy standoff. It was a dire situation, and film director Paul Greengrass attempted to bring this real-world piracy to the big screen, culminating in the film Captain Phillips, starring Tom Hanks as Captain Richard Phillips and Barkhad Abdi as Abduwali Muse. I must say, however, that I really was not expecting all that much from this movie, mostly because it is very hard to translate real-life events into film while still maintaining a certain degree of excitement and suspense. Yet, Captain Phillips legitimately surprised me, as I find the film to be one of the best of 2013.

I didn't quite know what to expect from this movie. I was vaguely familiar with the actual true life account. I was pleasantly surprised! This is one of the best movies of the year.  

It tells the real life account of a freighter captain that has been taken hostage by Somali pirates. The movie starts with the daily mundane tasks of a freighter captain and the routine run that they are making to deliver their cargo. They must pass by the Somali waters where pirate activity and hostage taking has become a serious problem in that part of the world. 

Somalia is located on the horn of Africa and is the location of the U.S. mission to capture a local warlord that went horribly wrong. The downing of Super 6-1 is commonly known as the black hawk down incident. The country of Somalia basically has no government and poverty and violence are just a way of everyday life. Many, such as the pirates, turn to crime to survive. The taking of hostages can be a very lucrative endeavor for these pirates, since the ransom money can be pretty substantial. 

When ships come under attack by pirates the crew has almost no means to defend themselves, save for water cannons mounted on the perimeter of the vessel. These water cannons can sometimes deter the pirates, but in this case the pirates were determined not to be stopped. 

When the pirates attack it is an intense moment but there is the feeling of safety you get when you see the pirates stopped again and again by the water cannons. The threat level they pose to you seems to lesson somewhat as one of the pirate boats is stopped. The other pirate boat continues the pursuit and is ultimately successful. The moment when the pirates grab onto the ship and start climbing up onto the deck is a moment of impending doom for the crew because now there is nothing they can do to get rid of the pirates. You feel this helplessness as they start to climb and the captain first sees them coming over the side on the deck. It is only a matter of time before they take over the ship and get their hostages. 

The movie is a not a special effects extravaganza that is very busy with the action sequences. The intense moments in this movie are grounded in reality. There is a subtlety to the movie that is refreshing in an era that is over saturated with special effects laden, over the top superhero movies. 

The actor that plays the leader of the pirates does a phenomenal job. He can convey a real feeling fear to the audience. You get a feel for what it would be like to have an encounter such as Captain Phillips did. 

The movie progresses at a good pace and it never drags or accelerates too quickly through the events. Even during the slower times in the movie, such as the time when all are in the life boat trying to escape with the hostage, you find yourself glued to the screen. 

It was an unexpected surprise for the writers tell portray one of the pirates as just a kid that has "fallen in with the wrong crowd". He is unsure of his situation and seems to have empathy for Phillips that the others don't. He doesn't seem to wish any real harm to him and seems to just wish that this situation were over so he could go home. 

SPOILER ALERT: When the SEAL snipers take out all the pirates you do feel sorry for this kid wondering what could have been had he had a chance for a different life or was able to leave Somalia for another country like America. 


The resolution of the situation by a team of Navy SEALS is satisfying end to the movie. Tom Hanks performance is always superb in all the movies that I've ever seen with him. He conveys to the audience very effectively what the real Captain Phillips was dealing with emotionally. 

How accurate this movie is to the real events is always suspect. Hollywood always has what seems as a disclaimer that doubles as a hook to get people to watch the movie: "Based on a true story". There are conflicting accounts from the media, crew members and Captain Phillips himself as to the events. His crew went as far to say that Phillips was a reckless Captain that always seemed to have some desire for adventure and intentionally steered the ships towards dangerous waters. Whether this is true or not is always debatable. It's basically a "he said she said" situation. 

An intriguing movie based on real-life events that doesn't disappoint. Highly recommend seeing this movie.

Tom Hanks not getting an Oscar nomination caused quite a controversy at the Oscars this year. Well I can tell you know what I believe was the right choice, my review of Captain Phillips now.

Based on the true story of Captain Richard's Phillips ship being taken over by Somalian Pirates. 

Holy crap....Just wow. Let me tell you that Captain Phillips without a doubt is one of the best movies of 2013, I mean one of the best. How Tom Hanks managed to get snubbed from this year is something I have no idea about.

All of the actors did really well but lets talk about our two stars. First off, Tom Hanks does his best acting in Saving Private Ryan, not quite as good but still he is mesmerizing in the lead role. I'm not a big fan of spoilers but I'm gonna tell you something right now so don't read it if you plan to watch the movie. ***The scene where Phillips is going into shock after being rescued was the shining moment in the entire movie. I couldn't believe it when Hanks was acting like he was going into shock, I FELT like he was actually going into shock! Tom Hanks was that believable in that one scene*** and that one scene along should have gotten him an Oscar nomination! Our other star of the movie is Barkhad Abdi, the leader of the Somalian pirate raid on the ship. So is Abdi's first ever move, first ever acting and he's great in the role. I mean, for a breakthrough role this is kind of shocking. While not like Hanks acting he does provide a lot of great scenes and constantly keeping to keep you at the edge of your seats.

Captain Phillips is also by far the most intense movie I have seen all year. Yes World War Z or The Hobbit were intense but nothing like this, remember this is based on a TRUE STORY. After the first twenty minutes pass getting to know the characters and the actual story comes in, there wasn't a moment where I wasn't indulged in the story! Tom Hanks trying his hardest to keep the pirates away was good but after they get on the boat and take him hostage, that is what killed me. You have no idea if any of the passengers are gonna come out alive or if the pirates will shoot and kill them. Then more spoilers sorry ***When Muse gets Phillips in the lifeboat and the navy is trying to get him out, holy crap.*** This entire movie is just intense and unbelievable. 

Another thing I really liked in the movie was the character interaction. The scenes between Phillips and Muse were by far the best of the movie. You have to remember that these pirates have these very large guns that could easily kill any crew member they wish to kill, it was a battle between Muse and Phillips trying to keep everyone alive. At times it would be Muse yelling at Phillips and threatening to kill him or even just the quiet conversations with them was just fantastic. Their acting abilities did really help them out.

Paul Greengrass's direction on the movie was spectacular. He made you feel seasick watching the movie. He had the cameras on the Somalian pirates boats and you could see the camera move up and down, watch splashing on it. I felt like I was actually on that boat when they were trying to take it. Then we have the lifeboat situation where everything is enclosed and you feel claustrophobic. He had made me feel a little claustrophobic watching the movie with the different closeups of the characters and the pirates battle to get pass the navy.

We have a lot more things to appreciate in this film like the screenplay. The dialogue between the characters not just the interaction was great. It wasn't cheesy, over the top, or anything. It was very strong and some of the best dialogue and one of the best screenplays of 2013. Then the music they played, loved that.

"Based on a true story." I never know what to expect when I read those words on a movie poster, especially when it is a high profile story where I already know the end result in the real world. I knew the general idea of what happened in Captain Phillips' ordeal with the pirates, so I wondered if they would be able to still pull off the tension of an attack at sea. Sure enough I was riveted. While you may know 1 or 2 key things that happen in the story, there are lots of little moments that should keep you on the edge of your seat. One of the more interesting aspects of the film is that, despite the title, it is not all focused on that one guy. We see a lot of events where Captain Phillips is merely the MacGuffin which brings a number of other characters together. This is initially set up in the opening scenes when, right after showing Phillips leaving for his trip, we are shown the pirates gathering their crew for the day. There are similar scenes later when the navy is gearing up to become involved in the situation. So, while we have a clear protagonist this isn't solely his movie, and the film doesn't go out of its way to artificially inflate him into some super action hero. In fact it almost gives the movie a documentary feel, which is also felt in the over use of handheld shaky camera. I really hated the shaky look of the film in the early scenes, but later I felt like things became more stable and I didn't need any more dramamine.

Tom Hanks should have received a best actor nomination, it's as simple as that. His accent was spot on, and he held it perfectly for most of the film. He seems so level-headed throughout the film, but as events continue to escalate around him, you can sense an underlying emotional roller coaster. This all culminates to the final scenes which I won't spoil for others, but I can say left me in tears. On the flip side I don't think Barkhad Abdi deserved a nomination for supporting actor. His performance did not contain much nuance, in fact it was somewhat flat and one-note. I felt like they were trying to prod me into feeling a bit sympathetic for his character because he was caught between a rock and a hard place, but I never was convinced and Abdi's performance lacked the underlying heart to get me there. The rest of the pirate crew (the only other significant characters in the film) were all typical movie bad guys. You've got your one young kid who's in over his head, and just kind of wants to go home. You've got your almost silent guy who's just trying to do his job without asking too many questions. And finally you've got your big muscle-bound guy who has rage issues, and creates a bunch of artificial tension simply by questioning his cohort who's supposed to be the one in charge. If you've seen any other movie or TV show with a hostage situation you'll probably recognize these personalities.

That is my biggest problem with Captain Phillips as a film. While it has the unique aspect of being a true story, it feels so carbon copy out of Hollywood Hostage Stories 101. Through no fault of their own I just kept thinking "I've seen this before." Now that's not a huge problem, because it is a quality story, but I just wanted more surprises. The opening had so much promise, because the battle with the pirate ship and the subsequent confrontation between the pirates and the crew were great. Yet eventually it became a hostage story, and I started losing interest. It doesn't help that the second half of this film really dragged. It was almost a constant cycle of yelling and bickering between the pirates, threatening to kill a hostage, and then agreeing that a dead hostage is worthless. Eventually things picked up, though, and the closing scenes were excellent and did a great job of recapturing that tension I felt in the beginning of the film. Perhaps if they had condensed things a bit and edited out some of the middle scenes it would have been even better, but I'm not sure if the final moments would have the same impact if the ordeal didn't feel so long. Either way, even with the lull that hit in the middle, I still found this to be a very good film. I won't be revisiting it any time soon, but I'm glad I was able to see one of the better movies from 2013.

Captain Phillips manages to deliver a great movie with some of Tom Hanks best acting coupled with some fantastic set pieces. It tells the tale of the first US cargo ship to be captured in over 200 years and it's based on a true story. Starting off with mentions has to be the plot; now while in my personal opinion it was well paced, I never felt the level of tension I feel the film wanted to create. They weren't terrorists with military weapons like normal action movies; they were just 4 men with 2 AK's. Because of this and the fact that (spoiler) no civilians are hurt for the movie, I feel as if the opportunity was wasted. Now the thing is, in a movie review like this, I can't make too much criticisms like that as its based on a true story and its not like they can change the story tot he way I like it or would have preferred. This was an experience that a human being actually went through and I can't even believe how traumatizing it must have been. For that, the actor that was picked had to deliver a riveting performance so as to replicate what he actually went through; and ladies and gentlemen, Tom Hanks delivers. He's no action hero; or a person with a specific set of skills; he's just a normal guy who was driving a boat to deliver some supplies. The movie does a really great way of showing this by introducing you to his wife in the beginning and the fact that they're having trouble with their kids; it humanizes him in a way and throughout the movie, Phillips spends most of his time with a gun in his face, scared. He's  not stupid, mind you, which is shown in his attempts to help his crew while on the ship. The main relationship that is focused on is that of Phillips and Muse, the Somali captain. Abdi does a great job of portraying a fisherman/pirate and as they spend time together in the movie, Phillips begins to understand his character and its at its peak in the final act with a powerful scene. Speaking of which, the somalis' mostly didn't speak english and while this may have been a turn off for some, I thought it was a good idea as it helped to further show that they were foreign; of different worlds. Phillips, from america where anything is possible, and Muse, from Somali where he's pressured to get money and trapped in a life he can't get out of. It's the small conversations that showcase the profound simplicity of these characters, such as when Muse tells him that he always wanted to go to America and buy a car. As stated before, I felt like the tension wasn't what it could have been, but the final act was strong, with tense action scenes and great music. While the focus was on the relationship, I felt no connection for the other characters; I suppose this is because it was mainly Phillips' story that was being told. The cinematography must also be praised with glorious shots of the sea in its beauty along with the the sheer differences in size of the Navy and the somalian fisherman boat. It's as if it was a metaphor for how America is the dominant super-power and has all the resources while Somali is currently suffering based on the event of the movie. I can imagine that it won't be for everyone; as even though there are some good action sequences, what really carries this movie is the acting and the story, which culminates with a fair ending.  One last thing; the height of Hanks performance was definitely in the final 5 minutes when he's being rescued. When he's in shock and begins to break down, it was earth-shattering. I've dealt with patients who have been in shock and its like he mirrored them perfectly. Great Job, Mr. Hanks. Good movie. 8/10

Paul Greengrass directs this magnificent, tense drama about a sea captain taken hostage by Somali pirates. based on a true story this is a real white knuckle ride as the action switches from the huge container ship Maersk Alabama as it is initially attacked by a small band of pirates, to the confines of the lifeboat in which the Somalis hold the ship's captain hostage. It is very effectively done and the final few scenes provide such a realistic portrayal of how such an ordeal affects an individual that I found it deeply upsetting. Tom Hanks takes the lead and this fine actor gives another masterclass in screen acting. He is simply brilliant as are his co-stars, especially the pirates, high on adrenaline and khat, who give a palpable depiction of their desperation. The scenes are well directed and the cramped and sweaty spaces of the ship corridors and lifeboat are well used to produce feelings of intense claustrophobia and panic. This really is an edge-of-your seat film and very worthwhile seeing.

This movie was very good and very intense.  It holds your attention and never lets go.  Director Paul Greengrass is great in the way he treated the story with a very straightforward, matter-of-fact approach (similar to how he did United 93) and with great attention to detail and technical accuracy.

The acting was great, aside from Tom Hanks's weird accent at the beginning (that seems to go away by the middle of the movie).  I really liked Tom Hanks's steady and clear-minded portrayal of Richard Phillips.  Phillips seemed to have a clear head, knew what he was doing, and was at least somewhat prepared for the threat.  I know a ton of accolades have been heaped on Barkhad Abdi's role as pirate leader Abduwali Muse, but while Abdi did fine, I barely noticed his performance in the movie, and I don't understand what all the hype is about.

I liked that the movie gave us a proper introduction to the pirates and the world they came from, almost making them sympathetic to a degree (though ultimately, I don't care how bad it is where you're from; there's no excuse for piracy).

The climax was very intense, and the effect was enhanced by the way the music built up to a crescendo and then went quiet in the immediate aftermath of the killing of the pirates, leaving the lifeboat silent except for whatever noise the lone surviving occupant - Phillips - was making.

I know it's been talked about to death already, but the ending scene where a shocked Phillips receives treatment from a Navy corpsman was really well-done.  It was unique in terms of how honest the portrayal of someone in shock was.  That said, there's a lot more to the movie than this one scene and I get annoyed when it's the only scene anyone will talk about.

I was pretty frustrated at how the crew of the ship didn't have guns, or any other projectile weapons they could've used to defend themselves or stop the pirates from boarding in the first place.  Also, one question that I had was, can the USA actually arrest, try, and imprison a foreign national, especially for a crime committed in international waters?

A good adaptation of a true story about the highjackings of ships for ransom by Somali pirates in the first decade of the 2000's. It's really a story of two men going to work, albeit in different ways, to sustain their survival in life. Captain Phillips, in charge of taking a container ship through the Red Sea by the dangerous horn of Africa and Muse, the Somali pirate forced by the barrel of the gun to hijack ships for ransom for the notorious Somali warlords. The accidental relationship between the two men brought to light aspects of humanity in both. Captain Phillips as the concerned and caring father that achieved much already in his life and Muse as the young man with dreams of making it in a better world despite his violent and desperate circumstances. Would the story have been centered more about that complex relationship rather than the shifting of the focus on the action of the navy seals in the heroic rescue of captain Phillips, the movie would have been more impactant and deep. The action and the rescue made it into another heroic story of military rescue, Hollywood style, as if we needed more of that!

It must be hard not to like Tom Hanks. He's always seemed like such a jovial, fun-loving person, the kind of guy you can have a few drinks with at a party and just laugh and laugh at his stories and anecdotes.

And, lest we forget, the man is one hell of an actor.

I don't know Tom Hanks. I've never spent any time with him, nor have I ever even met him personally. Therefore, I can't verify anything in my first paragraph above. These are just impressions I get from the guy, and from these impressions, I'm making guesses. It's all just speculation.

But there's no speculation involved in the sentence directly preceding the above paragraph. That is a cold, hard fact. I don't need to go through the man's filmography to illustrate this, but if you're looking for recent proof, just rent "Captain Phillips." You'll get all the proof you need...and maybe then you'll understand my shock that the guy was somehow snubbed of a Best Actor nomination this year.

The funny thing is that, as much as "Captain Phillips" is a showcase for Hanks' ability as an actor, it's also quite easy to forget you're watching a performance (or even a movie, at times). Despite his star power, I often forgot I was watching Tom Hanks. He simply BECAME Captain Richard Phillips of New Jersey. The movie sometimes takes on a documentary-like feel. That's how effective both Hanks and the film really are. Like fellow Best Picture nominee "Gravity," "Captain Phillips" is a masterful example of a prolonged exercise in tension.

As the film opens, Captain Richard Phillips (Hanks) is piloting the container ship MV Maersk Alabama to Mombasa, Kenya. This is a perilous venture because the route is going to take the ship past the coast of Somalia, a hotspot for pirate activity. Sure enough, the ship is attacked and eventually boarded by a small band of Somali pirates, led by Muse (Barkhad Abdi). They plan on ransoming the ship and crew for millions of dollars in insurance money from the shipping company.

This is a recent story, so there's a good chance most audience members will be familiar with how this plays out. But that does nothing to diminish the white-knuckled tension permeating throughout the movie. Captain Phillips does his best to placate his pirate aggressors, but they're like a powder keg waiting to go off; one wrong move, and everybody dies. And although they're clearly destitute, they're certainly not simpletons, especially their leader, Muse. He's intelligent, calculating, and--perhaps most dangerous of all--determined.

Director Paul Greengrass utlizes the same gritty, shaky-cam technique of his previous efforts (including "United 93," "The Bourne Ultimatum," and the underrated "Green Zone") and the effect is intoxicating and claustrophobic, and I mean that as a compliment. There are times when we feel like we're right there with Phillips and his captors.

Hanks' performance is about as real and raw as you can get, but I must also praise Somali newcomer Barkhad Abdi as the pirate leader. It's always risky to cast newcomers or non-actors in major roles opposite big name stars (e.g., Clint Eastwood's "Gran Torino"), but Abdi goes toe-to-toe with Hanks, even managing to garner some sympathy for the desperate Muse. We get the sense that he is not an evil man; he's simply playing the hand he was dealt. The movie doesn't make excuses for his actions, but it does dare the audience to think about what they would do if they were in his shoes.

"Captain Phillips" is the kind of film that leaves you gasping and feeling wrung-out. It's merciless and unrelenting, but the efforts of Hanks, Abdi and Greengrass make it an extraordinary film. You should definitely check it out.

While "Captain Phillips" engages with some compelling questions with regards to power and economics, it's tough to feel that it ever engages with them to the degree that it might. The whole thing is still fundamentally an action movie, with the white man framed as protagonist and the black man as antagonist, and, while it's certainly more complicated than that, the bulk of the movie is spent on the action, and the audience with which I saw it seemed content to cheer on the Navy and even to laugh in spots at the mishaps of the Somali pirates. I think "Captain Phillips" is trying to do something good, and I even think it accomplishes its worthy goals to a large degree, and I'm certainly not going to complain about Greengrass' choice to eschew sentimentality (at least until the final few minutes) in favor of a more objective, procedural approach, but I'm left with the feeling that we're never provided enough context. Not enough context for the action to be coherent, in certain cases, too much context, in a way, for the suspense to be suspenseful (knowing going in that Phillips escapes relatively unharmed really deflates the dramatic sails), not enough context for me to really connect with any of the characters beyond the most superficial level, and not enough context for the larger issues it's tackling to really mean much.

Probably not the "complex portrait of the myriad effects of globalization" that it claims to be; as a thinkpiece, Captain Phillips has an intriguing foil in Barkhad Abdi's lead pirate and not a whole lot else. But as a gray-shaded thriller, Captain Phillips delivers, particularly in the second half when clunky exposition is thrown to the wayside. Hanks is obviously great but Abdi is the true star of the show, sympathetic while never sinking anywhere near some "pirate with a heart of gold" cliche. But more than anything else, Greengrass knows how to stage a ludicrously stressful situation and keep the pressure on for the full two hours.

This film can be amazing at times but is also riddled with problems.  The movie gets the plot going rather quickly, basically within 20 minutes.  After that, the film becomes amazingly engrossing for the next 45 minutes or so.  There was a period of like 30 minutes where I legitimately couldn't turn away.  The film was that entertaining.  But it's also way too long.  This would've been a phenomenal 90 minute film.  But after Phillips gets kidnapped, the film starts to go downhill.  The excellent pacing and tense atmosphere found in the film's first half basically disappear.  The film quickly becomes repetitive: the kidnappers threaten Phillips, he begs them not to hurt him, and finds some way to convince them to not hurt him; he then continues to find ways to undermine them.  Splice in some shots of people negotiating with the kidnappers and the SEALs readying their weapons on the Navy destroyer, rinse and repeat.  The film just keeps showing the same stuff over and over again for the last 45 minutes, and it really almost kills the film.  It certainly makes it drag, and having been, well, enraptured by the first half, I find myself losing interest and becoming bored.  This could've been an amazing film...instead it was basically reduced to mediocrity by awful editing and poor pacing.

The only reason I sat through Captain Phillips was due to its Best Picture Oscar nomination.  To which I say to the Academy: Really?  REALLY?
	Captain Phillips is a tediously long, drawn out, anti-action, illogical, impractical bore.
	Paul Greengrass might have been successful employing his hand-held, unsteady cam technical approach in United 93.  But that technique here makes the film come across as a shaky, rocky and distracting (from the tension of the character based drama) failure.  Captain Phillips is not Cloverfield.  Plus it takes place on a freighter - not  in a canoe.  
	Another thing  -  the completely wasted and trite 2 minute opening sequence.  Where Captain Richard Phillips leaves his home accompanied by his wife (Kathleen Keener, forgettable) for the sole reason of "grounding" an engaging, concerning, serious moment where they discuss the security and safey of his job.  Greengrass should have just cut this cardboard, poorly written, ineffective bit. Cut.  It. Out. Leave it on the editing floor.  Along with the rest of the movie.
	Another thing - the Somali pirates.  There were no subtitles.   Don't think it was the version I watched.  But .... what the hell were they talking about?  What the hell were they saying?  Physical and emotional reactions are one thing.  Yet when you can't understand the language, you technically have a HARDER time getting into their characters.  Which honest I did much at all.    I would completely understand if they didn't have subtitles during the moments when the Somalians were taking the ship hostage.  Such lack of subtitles could have been successful in invoking a feeling of the shipmates inability of understanding  what was being said.  Which would have installed a definite sense of tension and fearfulness.  Yet at the beginning when the pirate captain (Barkhad Abdi, who looked too similar to most of the other Somalian pirates/actors in the film which made him loose a deeper sense of identity)  was choosing his other band mates, I felt I could not connect to the importance nor the intensity of the scene.
	Another thing - the implausibility of the whole hostage take over.  So a ship carrying cargo through treacherous international waters not auto-guarded by the UN to third world war inflicted countries doesn't have guns?  Of any short?  Besides flare missels?  Really?  REALLY?  Mathematically speaking, the MV Maersk Alabama had a crew of what?  Twelve? Sixteen? Even more?  Against a band of 4 or 5 pirates?  Huh?  Yes the pirates did have automatic machine guns.  But like Captain Phillips speechified before they were boarded: "Remember that you know the ship.  They don't." So a macho-men crew of 12+ on their own "home turf"  couldn't take The Expendables gutsy action to devise a plan to fight back?  Sigourney Weaver done it.  Jodi Foster has done it.  Angelia Jolie even.  But shipmen can't?   Really?  REALLY?  Sure.  Fine.  Whatever.  To me I just find it implausible and completely unbelievable. 
	One last thing before I let your eyeballs go... or you stab me with your "Ryan I LOVED IT! You overly critical bastard" pitchfork.   Tom Hanks.  Tom Hanks doesn't drive me to watch anything.  From the previews Tom Hank's attempt at an accent even turned me off (in the movie it's completely inconsistent.  And still annoying).  His acting and embodiment of Richard Phillips - except for a handful of scenes - is that of a fearful, timid man.  And at times gutless. Especially on the lifeboat where Greengrass resorts to close-ups of Hank's petrified, sweaty face to provoke an empathic  reaction out of us.  Then when Hanks speaks the assigned banal and uninspiring dialogue, it completely dissolves any sympathy and tension.  The one recent Tom Hanks role (or roles) where I actually enjoyed him in was Cloud Atlas.  Otherwise, his only memorable movies to me were The Green Mile (1999), Forrest Gump (1994), and iconically BIG (1984).  RIP Esteemed Actor Tom Hanks, RIP.

Is it strange that I found A Hijacking to feel a little more real than this film, even though the former isn't based on a true story and the latter is.  A Hijacking, if you're unaware, is a film detailing a similar situation to this film except it also looks at the emotional stress of those handling the hostage negotiation, on top of the duress the crew goes through during their ordeal.  It is an excellent film, but a quietly intense one at that.  If you're stuck between watching this or A Hijacking and you're looking for a film heavy on "action" and suspense, then this film is the way to go.  But if you love films, you'll go out of your way to watch both.  The thing about A Hijacking is the fact that it focuses more on the negotiations between the pirates and the company that owns the ship.  There's a lot of going back and forth between them, so the film is very dialogue heavy, and some of the most important scenes in the film, such as the hijacking itself, are done off-screen.  So the film subverts expectations for this genre of film, it's a little more understated and, therefore, a little more realistic.  Not to take anything away from this film, and I don't doubt anything that happened in this film, but I also found it to be like a heavily dramatized account of the real life story.  And that's understandable, particularly if you want a wide audience to invest in your story, you exaggerate things a little bit more for the dramatic effect.  Again, I don't doubt that this was a horrific thing that happened to the people on the ship and, later, to Captain Phillips after he's taken hostage on the lifeboat, but the film is a little bit more dramatically manipulative than it probably wants to let on.  That doesn't mean that the dramatic freedoms they took made the film worse.  In actuality, I think that's why part of the film is as good as it is.  Paul Greengrass knows how to direct intense and suspenseful movies, and this film is no different.  He's got the same cinema-verite style that makes it feel like you're almost part of the crew stuck in the same situation, I think the uncertainty of the situation translates incredibly thanks to its cinematography and camerawork.  With that said, while I complain about the film not feeling like an accurate representation of what happened, that doesn't mean that the style in which the film was presented is bad, or anything of the sort.  Again, for what Paul Greengrass is trying to present, it works perfectly.  It's just strange finding a film, that's inspired by real-life events but not actually based on one, feel more realistic than a film that IS based on a real-life situation.  That doesn't speak, at all, to the quality of each individual film.  It's just an observation.  But moving on, I did find that the movie, after the pirates take captain Phillips hostage on the lifeboat, slows down...almost to a complete halt.  Almost as slow as the lifeboat they were in on, like they were just trying to kill time before the climax came.  Not that I can blame them for that, you need to pace yourself before the big climax...that's more than understandable.  You need the lows in order to appreciate the highs even more.  If the film had been a constant high, then you'd have been numbed by it all by the end of the film.  But I still think that they could've shortened these parts up a bit in order to make the film tighter and more concise.  Regardless of its length, I still found this film to be an easy watch, but there's still some stuff that could've been cut out that wasn't needed.  With that said, the actual climax of the film itself, with the Navy Seals trying to secure the targets in the lifeboat, was outstanding and probably the main reason the film gets the rating it did.  Greengrass has this way of just getting the most out of these situations.  If it takes him 20 minutes to get where he needs to go, then so be it, but he's doing it for a reason.  He's doing it in order to create tension, suspense, and the uncertainty that something may happen that could fuck all this up, even if you know of the real life case.  So props to Greengrass and the crew for doing this like true pros.  Tom Hanks is outstanding, but what else do you expect from him.  He's strong and commanding, yet incredibly vulnerable at the same time.  He doesn't know if he's gonna make it out alive out of this situation, so the fact that he manages to stay so calm in this situation rather than breaking out in hysterics is a testament to Hanks' strengths as an actor.  I liked the story as well as it, in a more understated manner, highlights the problem that globalization has on the economy of some of these third-world countries.  Not that the film paints a favorable portrait of the pirates, which it doesn't, but it does give a potential reason for why they've decided to become pirates.  So the film is much more than just the hijacking.  If you can, seek out both this and A Hijacking because they're equally as different but for completely different reasons.
